moves.1. e4 e6 2. d4 d5: the french defence. I play french, petrov, caro, Alekhine, 2 knights chigorin gambit (against the Ng5 attack) regularly.
moves.3. e5: the advance variation. This move is now played a lot more at the master level these days, but the main idea of the french for white is Nd2 or Nc3, which I respond with rubenstein's dxe4, if a draw is what I want.
moves.3... c5: this move is almost always played.
moves.4. b3: what the?! I have never seen this. If I didn't know my opponent, I would think that he is either very strong or a beginner. Turns out he's neither, but...
moves.4... cxd4 5. Qxd4 Nc6 6. Bb5: here, I begin to realize I may have tactical chances if white plays incorrectly.
moves.6... Qa5+ 7. Nc3 Bb4: My first thought is that this forces white to play Bishop takes knight ch, which I respond b takes c6, and I white will have to call off the fianchetto because of ideas like c5 and d4 bombing the knight on c3.
moves.8. Bxc6+ bxc6 9. Nge2: blunder on the 9th move, It seems like I win with Ba6 or c5. After making sure he does not have counters involving the h8 rook, I play the c5 d4
moves.11. Bb2 Ba6 12. Qe4 Rc8: I figure I have enough material to win after I get the knight, retreat, safeguard my position, and then attack his position with my extra material.
moves.13. O-O Bxc3 14. Bxc3 dxc3: the rest of the game is easy, so enjoy.
